title: Teaching
text:
I am teaching the following courses at Carnegie Mellon University (order by course level):

46–924 Natural Language Processing (mini)
Elective course on natural language processing for the Master’s in Computational Finance program, text mining, topic models, and transformers.


46–926 Machine Learning I (mini)
Core course on statistical machine learning for the Master’s in Computational Finance program, including regression, classification, and tree-based methods.


36-460/660 Special Topics: Sports Analytics
Elective course for advanced undergraduate and master’s level students on sports analytics methods, including multilevel models, Bayesian statistics, and spatio-temporal data.


36–613 Data Visualization (mini)
Core course in Master of Science in Applied Data Science (MADS) on creating and understanding data visualizations and interactive tools from a statistical perspective.


36-642 Telling Impactful Stories with Data Visualization (online mini)
Data visualization course in Foundations of Data Science online graduate certificate program.


36-493 Sports Analytics Capstone
Undergraduate capstone course using data provided by CMU athletics for sports analytics research projects.


36-315 Statistical Graphics and Visualization
Undergraduate course on creating and understanding data visualizations from a statistical perspective.

title: Ron Yurko
text:
I am an Assistant Teaching Professor in the Department of Statistics & Data Science at Carnegie Mellon University. My research focuses on developing methods at the interface of inference and machine learning, oriented towards problems in sports analytics and natural language processing.
Interested in sports analytics? Check out what CMSAC has to offer, including:

Carnegie Mellon Sports Analytics Conference
Summer Undergraduate Research Experience (aka CMSACamp)
Open Source Sports Substack

If you’re a CMU student interested in sports analytics, I recommend signing up for my Sports Analytics special topics course 36-460/660.

title: About
text:
I am an Assistant Teaching Professor in the Department of Statistics & Data Science at Carnegie Mellon University. My research focuses on developing methods at the interface of inference and machine learning, oriented towards problems in sports analytics and natural language processing.
I previously received my PhD in Statistics at Carnegie Mellon University under supervision of Professor Kathryn Roeder and Max G’Sell. My thesis work focused on selective inference approaches for augmenting genetic association studies with data-guided hypothesis testing.
